\section{Smoothings and Fano threefolds}
We prove the main theorem, after which we present several remarks and examples.
\begin{thm} Let $S$ be a general K3 surface of genus $g$. The affine cone over $S$ is smoothable if and only if $g\le10$ or $g=12$.
\end{thm}
\begin{proof} Let $X=C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ denote the affine cone over $S$. If $g=11$ or $g\ge13$, then $X$ has only conical deformations by Corollary \ref{cor!neg} and Proposition \ref{prop!schlessinger-conditions}. If $g\le10$ or $g=12$ then by \cite[Corollary 4.1]{Beauville}, $S$ is an anticanonical member of 
	a smooth Fano 3-fold $W$, that is, $S \in |{-}K_W|$. Let $C_a(W,-K_W)$ be the affine cone over the pair $(W, -K_W)$. 
	Let $\mathcal{X} \subset C_a(W, -K_W) \times \mathbb{A}^1$ be a divisor defined by a function $\sigma + \lambda$, 
	where $\sigma \in H^0(W, -K_W)$ is the defining section of $S$ and $\lambda$ is the parameter of the affine line $\mathbb{A}^1$. 
	Then we have a deformation $\mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{A}^1$ of $X$. 
	


The fibre over $0$ is $X$, and the general fibre ${\mathcal{X}}_t$ is nonsingular, because the general fibers avoid the vertex. 
This is a smoothing of $X$ by sweeping out the anticanonical member of $W$.
\end{proof}

\subsection{The cone over a K3 surface with $g=11$ or $g\ge13$ can nevertheless be smoothable} If a K3 surface $S$ is an anticanonical section of a Fano 3-fold with $b_2\ge 2$ from the Mori--Mukai classification \cite{MM},
then $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ is smoothable. Thus there are K3 surfaces of genus $11$ and $\ge13$ whose affine
cone is smoothable. For such K3 surfaces, Theorem \ref{thm!vanishing} does not apply, and $H^1(\Omega^1_S(L))$ does not vanish.

\begin{eg} Let $S$ be a hypersurface of bidegree $(2,3)$ in ${\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^2$. Since $S$ is a section of $|{-K_{{\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^2}}|$, we see that $(S,-K_{{\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^2}|_S)$ is a K3 surface of genus $28$. Nevertheless, we obtain a smoothing of the affine cone $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$, simply by sweeping out the cone inside $C_a({\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^2,{-K_{{\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^2}})$.
\end{eg}

\begin{eg}
Suppose $S$ is a K3 of genus $13$. By \cite{MM}, there are five distinct deformation families of Fano 3-folds with $g=13$. Two each with $b_2=2$ and $b_2=3$, and one with $b_2=4$. The cone $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ over a general $S$ is not smoothable, but if we specialise $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$  to $C_a(S',{\mathcal O}(1))$ where $S'$ is the hyperplane section of one of the above Fano 3-folds, then $C_a(S',{\mathcal O}(1))$ is smoothable.
Thus we see that there are at least five strata in the moduli space of genus 13 K3 surfaces, for which the cone over a K3 surface in such a stratum is smoothable.
\end{eg}

\begin{eg}
Similarly, if $S$ is a K3 of genus 11, then by \cite{MM}, there are four families of Fano 3-folds with $g=11$. Three with $b_2=2$ and one with $b_2=3$. The general K3 of genus 11 is not a hyperplane section of any Fano 3-fold.
\end{eg}

\subsection{K3 surfaces of genus $>32$} Suppose $S$ is a K3 surface of genus $\ge13$. The only smoothings of $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ that we know of, are induced by Fano 3-folds appearing in the classification of Mori--Mukai \cite{MM}, in the same way as the above examples. If $S$ has genus $>32$, exceeding the maximum appearing in \cite{MM}, then any smoothing of $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ does not lift to the projective cone $C_p(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$. In spite of Example \ref{ex!non-proj-smoothing}, we expect that $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ is not smoothable for \emph{any} $S$ of sufficiently large genus. An equivalent question (cf.~\cite[\S5.4]{Beauville}) is the following:
\begin{quote}
Is ${\varphi}_{g,k}$ actually finite and unramified for $g>32$? 
\end{quote}

\subsection{K3 surfaces whose affine cone has at least two distinct smoothings}\label{sec!two-smoothings}
We give an example of a K3 surface $S$ of genus $7$ which is a hyperplane section of two topologically distinct anticanonical Fano 3-folds. It follows that the affine cone $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}(1))$ has two topologically distinct smoothings, obtained by sweeping out the cone over the two different Fano 3-folds. First recall the following famous example:

\begin{eg}\label{rem!dp6} The degree 6 del Pezzo surface $Y$ is a hyperplane section of $V_1=V\colon(1,1)\subset{\mathbb P}^2\times{\mathbb P}^2$ and $V_2={\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^1\times{\mathbb P}^1$. Thus $C_a(Y,{-K_Y})$ has two distinct smoothings. 
\end{eg}
Inspired by this, we found the following example:
\begin{eg}\label{ex!K3-double-dp6}
	Let $Y$ be the degree 6 del Pezzo surface, and take $\pi\colon S\to Y$ a double cover branched in $B\in|{-2K_Y}|$. Then $S$ is a K3 surface of degree 12 in ${\mathbb P}^7$. By Example \ref{rem!dp6}, $Y=V_i\cap H_i$ for some $H_i\in|{-\frac12K_{V_i}}|$. Take $\pi_i\colon W_i\to V_i$ a double cover branched in $X_i\in|{-K_{V_i}}|$, where $X_i$ are chosen so that $X_i\cap H_i=B$ since $H^0(V_i, -K_{V_i}) \rightarrow H^0(Y, -2K_Y)$ is surjective. The $W_i$ are Fano 3-folds with distinct topology. Indeed, $W_1$ (respectively $W_2$) is number 2.6b (resp.~3.1) of the classification \cite{MM}. Moreover, both $W_1$ and $W_2$ contain $S$ as a section of $|{-K_{W_i}}|$, because $W_i\cap\pi_i^*H_i=S$. Thus the affine cone $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}_S(1))$ is a hyperplane section of $C_a(W_i,-K_{W_i})\subset{\mathbb A}^{9}$ for each $i$, and so $C_a(S,{\mathcal O}_S(1))$ has two topologically distinct smoothings.
\end{eg}


\subsection{Hyperelliptic and trigonal K3 surfaces} In view of Theorem \ref{thm!keq2}, it would be interesting to systematically study cones over hyperelliptic and trigonal K3 surfaces, and other K3 surfaces with Clifford index $\le2$. These K3 surfaces are not general in the sense of Theorem \ref{thm!main}. For example, we would expect that the genus bound on smoothable cones over hyperelliptic K3 surfaces is given by the genus bound on hyperelliptic Fano 3-folds.



\subsection{Quasismooth K3 surfaces} It would be very interesting to generalise Theorem \ref{thm!main} to the case of affine cones over quasismooth K3 surfaces embedded in weighted projective space. Some applications of this are worked out in \cite{K3-transitions}. This motivates future work.
